text: our brains spend pretty much all day
every day trying to make sense of what
we're seeing the brain can interpret an
image a mere 13 milliseconds after we
see it but we still don't catch
everything for our visual system to
handle everything we see our brains
would need to be larger than a house for
that reason our brains cut corners
choosing the most likely interpretation
of what our eyes take in in a fraction
of a second so can we trust our brain is
seem really believing this is not the
result of CGI or LSD what you're seeing
here is a famous mathematical sequence
the sculpture is moving but not how you
think it's not going up and down just
around and around very fast created by
artist John Eadie mark these 3d printed
sculptures called blooms spin that 550
rotations per minute while a camera with
a shutter speed of 1/4 thousandth of a
second slows down the image a strobe
light flashes each time the sculpture
turns exactly one hundred and thirty
seven point five degrees the degree in
which each petal sticks out it's an
angle related to the legendary
phenomenon known as the Fibonacci
sequence the Fibonacci sequence is a
series of numbers each number in the
sequence is the sum of the two numbers
before it when represented in geometric
form it creates a spiral and we can see
this pattern all around us in nature
from sunflowers to shells to artichokes
this specific spiral illusion is what
makes the sculpture look like it's not
just spinning but undulating another
reason we perceive the balloons moving
this way is our brains frame rate its
cff critical flicker frequency which
operates at around 60 frames a second
allowing you to see the movement and
strobing as one continuous image and
embrace the illusion so is
really believing not when nature's
equation is messing with your mind
you
